title: Classic Shakshuka
description: North African eggs poached in spicy tomato sauce with peppers and onions. A beloved Israeli breakfast staple served with fresh bread for dipping.

recipe.text: Shakshuka is one of Israel's most iconic dishes. While its origins trace to North Africa, it has become a cornerstone of Israeli cuisine. The key is getting the sauce rich and flavorful before adding the eggs.
Ingredients

items: Salt and black pepper to taste
Warm pita or challah for serving

recipe.text: Instructions
1. Heat olive oil in a large deep skillet or cast iron pan over medium heat. Add the diced onion and bell pepper, cooking for about 8-10 minutes until softened and starting to caramelize.
2. Add the minced garlic, cumin, paprika, and cayenne. Stir constantly for about 1 minute until fragrant. This step is crucial for developing deep flavor.

3. Pour in the crushed tomatoes and add sugar, salt, and pepper. Stir well and let the sauce simmer for 15-20 minutes, stirring occasionally, until it thickens and becomes rich. Taste and adjust seasoning.
4. Using a spoon, create 6 wells in the sauce. Carefully crack an egg into each well. Season the eggs with a pinch of salt and pepper.
5. Cover the pan and cook for 5-8 minutes, depending on how you like your eggs. For runny yolks, check at 5 minutes. For fully set eggs, cook the full 8 minutes.
6. Remove from heat and garnish generously with fresh herbs and feta if using. Serve immediately with warm bread for scooping up the sauce and eggs.
Pro Tips

• Make the sauce a day ahead for even deeper flavor
• Add harissa paste for extra heat and complexity
• Try adding spinach or kale in the last few minutes of cooking the sauce
• Serve with labneh or tahini on the side

title: Authentic Sabich
description: Israeli street food sandwich with fried eggplant, hard-boiled eggs, Israeli salad, tahini, and amba in fresh pita. Originated from Iraqi Jewish immigrants.

recipe.text: Sabich is peak Israeli street food - a pita stuffed with fried eggplant, eggs, and salads. The combination of textures and the tangy amba (pickled mango sauce) make it unforgettable. Worth every minute of prep!
For the Eggplant
For Israeli Salad
For Assembly
Instructions

1. Slice eggplants into 1/2-inch rounds. Sprinkle generously with salt on both sides and let sit in a colander for 30 minutes to draw out moisture and bitterness. Pat completely dry with paper towels.
2. Heat about 1/2 inch of vegetable oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Fry eggplant slices in batches until golden brown on both sides, about 3-4 minutes per side. Drain on paper towels.
3. Make the Israeli salad: Combine all salad ingredients in a bowl and toss well. The key is very fine, uniform dice. Set aside to let flavors meld.
4. To assemble: Warm pitas slightly. Cut open to create a pocket. Layer in: fried eggplant, sliced hard-boiled egg, generous Israeli salad, tahini drizzle, amba, zhug if using, and pickles.
5. Don't be shy with the sauces - the tahini and amba are what make sabich special. Wrap tightly and eat immediately while the eggplant is still warm.

title: Jerusalem Mixed Grill (Me'orav Yerushalmi)
description: A famous Jerusalem street food of mixed grilled chicken parts with onions, garlic, and Middle Eastern spices served in pita or laffa.

recipe.text: Me'orav Yerushalmi is Jerusalem's ultimate street food - a mix of grilled chicken hearts, spleens, and other parts, though this home version uses more accessible chicken thighs and livers while maintaining authentic flavors.
Ingredients

items: 1 lb chicken thighs, cut into small pieces
1/2 lb chicken livers, cleaned and halved
Tahini and hot sauce for serving

recipe.text: Instructions
1. Heat a large cast iron skillet or flat griddle over high heat. Add olive oil and let it get very hot - this is key for proper charring.
2. Add the onions first and cook for 5-6 minutes, stirring occasionally, until they start to char and soften. Push to the sides.
3. Add chicken thighs to the center. Season with half the spices and salt. Cook without stirring for 3-4 minutes to get good browning.

4. Add chicken livers (and hearts if using). Add remaining spices and the minced garlic. Stir everything together and continue cooking for 4-5 minutes. The livers should be cooked through but still tender.
5. Squeeze lemon juice over everything and toss. Taste and adjust salt. The mixture should be well-spiced and have nice charred bits.
6. Serve immediately in warm laffa or pita with tahini, hot sauce, Israeli salad, and pickles. Garnish with fresh parsley.

title: Israeli Schnitzel with Side Salads
description: Crispy breaded chicken cutlets served with classic Israeli salads - cabbage slaw, Israeli salad, and pickles. A weeknight dinner staple.

recipe.text: In Israel, schnitzel isn't just a dish - it's a way of life. Crispy, thin, and perfectly seasoned, served with vibrant salads. Every family has their technique for the crispiest coating.
For the Schnitzel

items: 4 chicken breasts, butterflied and pounded thin

recipe.text: Cabbage Slaw
Israeli Salad

items: Lemon juice, olive oil, salt, pepper

recipe.text: Instructions

1. Prepare the salads first so they can rest: For cabbage slaw, massage the shredded cabbage with salt for 5 minutes, then rinse and squeeze dry. Toss with carrots, lemon juice, oil, sugar, salt and pepper. For Israeli salad, simply combine all ingredients.
2. Set up breading station: Place flour in one shallow dish, beaten eggs in another, and breadcrumbs mixed with garlic powder, paprika, salt, and pepper in a third.

3. Pat chicken completely dry. Season both sides with salt and pepper. Dredge each piece: flour (shake off excess) → egg (let excess drip) → breadcrumbs (press firmly to adhere). Place on a wire rack.
4. Heat 1/4 inch oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Oil is ready when a breadcrumb sizzles immediately when dropped in.
5. Fry schnitzels 2 at a time, about 3-4 minutes per side until deep golden brown. Don't overcrowd the pan. Drain on paper towels and season with a pinch of salt immediately.
6. Serve hot with both salads, lemon wedges, and pita bread on the side. Squeeze fresh lemon over the schnitzel just before eating.

title: Yemenite Jachnun
description: Slow-cooked overnight rolled pastry from Yemen, crispy on the outside, soft inside. Served with grated tomato, zhug, and hard-boiled eggs.

recipe.text: Jachnun is the ultimate Shabbat breakfast. Yemenite Jews would prepare it Friday afternoon and let it slow-cook overnight, ready for Saturday morning. The result is buttery, caramelized layers of tender dough.
Ingredients

items: 1 cup (2 sticks) butter, very soft or clarified

recipe.text: For Serving
Instructions
1. Make the dough: Mix flour, salt, and sugar in a large bowl. Gradually add warm water, kneading until smooth and elastic, about 10 minutes. The dough should be soft and pliable.
2. Divide dough into 8 equal pieces and roll into balls. Coat each ball generously with soft butter, place on a tray, cover with plastic wrap, and rest for at least 3 hours (or overnight in fridge).
3. On a well-buttered surface, stretch each ball into a very thin rectangle (almost translucent). This takes practice - be patient and gentle. Spread more butter over the surface.

4. Roll up tightly from one long side to form a log, then coil the log into a tight spiral. Place spirals upright in a deep, heavy pot (they should fit snugly). Add raw eggs in their shells to the gaps between rolls.
5. Pour 1/2 cup water around the edges. Cover tightly with aluminum foil and then the lid. Place in 225°F (110°C) oven overnight (10-12 hours). Check once that there's still some liquid.

6. In the morning, carefully remove jachnun (it will be very soft). Serve warm with grated fresh tomato, zhug, and peeled hard-boiled eggs. The eggs will have a creamy texture and slight caramel color from slow cooking.
Note
If you don't have 12 hours, you can cook at 250°F for 6-8 hours, though the traditional method yields better results.

title: Malawach with Grated Tomato
description: Flaky Yemenite flatbread, pan-fried until crispy and golden, served with fresh grated tomato and zhug. A beloved breakfast treat.

recipe.text: Malawach is flaky, buttery perfection. Unlike jachnun (which is baked), malawach is pan-fried, creating crispy, golden layers. It's often served for breakfast with grated tomato, but it's delicious any time.
Ingredients
For Serving

items: 4-5 ripe tomatoes, grated on box grater

recipe.text: Instructions
1. Mix flour, salt, and sugar in a bowl. Add warm water gradually and knead for 8-10 minutes until smooth and elastic. Cover and rest for 30 minutes.

2. Divide dough into 6 pieces and roll into balls. Coat each generously with soft butter and place on a greased tray. Cover and refrigerate for at least 4 hours or overnight - this is crucial for flakiness.
3. On a heavily buttered surface, use a rolling pin (or your hands) to stretch each ball into a very thin circle, about 12 inches in diameter. The thinner, the flakier!
4. Fold the circle in half, then in half again to form a triangle. Or fold it into a square. Either way works - you're creating layers.
5. Heat a large skillet or griddle over medium heat. No need to add oil - there's enough butter in the dough. Cook each malawach for 3-4 minutes per side until golden brown with crispy edges.
6. While cooking, prepare grated tomato: Cut tomatoes in half and grate on the large holes of a box grater (discard skins). Season with salt.
7. Serve malawach hot, torn into pieces for dipping in the grated tomato and zhug. Add hard-boiled eggs on the side for a complete breakfast.

title: Authentic Hummus
description: Creamy, smooth hummus made from scratch with dried chickpeas. Topped with olive oil, paprika, and pine nuts. Nothing beats homemade.

recipe.text: True hummus in Israel is an art form - impossibly smooth, rich with tahini, and perfectly balanced. The secret is using dried chickpeas, cooking them until they almost fall apart, and blending with patience.
Ingredients

items: For topping: olive oil, paprika, pine nuts, parsley

recipe.text: Instructions
1. Soak chickpeas overnight in plenty of water with the baking soda. They'll double in size. Drain and rinse the next day.

2. Place chickpeas in a large pot with fresh water (about 3 times their volume). Bring to a boil, then reduce to a simmer. Cook for 1.5 to 2 hours until the chickpeas are extremely soft - they should squish easily between your fingers. Skim off any foam or skins that float up.
3. Drain chickpeas but reserve the cooking liquid. Let chickpeas cool slightly - you want them warm but not burning hot.
4. In a food processor, blend garlic first until minced. Add tahini, lemon juice, cumin, and salt. Process for 1-2 minutes - the mixture will seize up and become thick. This is normal!
5. With the processor running, slowly drizzle in the ice water. The mixture will become smooth and light in color. This step is key for creamy hummus.

6. Add the warm chickpeas (reserve a few for garnish). Blend for 3-4 minutes, scraping down sides as needed. If too thick, add a little cooking liquid. Blend until completely smooth and almost fluffy.
7. Taste and adjust salt, lemon, or tahini. Transfer to a wide, shallow bowl. Create a well in the center and fill with olive oil. Top with reserved whole chickpeas, paprika, pine nuts, and parsley.
8. Serve immediately with warm pita bread. Hummus is best enjoyed fresh, at room temperature.

title: Crispy Falafel
description: Deep-fried chickpea fritters with herbs and spices. Crispy outside, fluffy green inside. A Middle Eastern classic perfect in pita or over salad.

recipe.text: The key to perfect falafel is using dried chickpeas soaked overnight - never canned! This creates the right texture: crispy exterior with a fluffy, herb-flecked interior.
Ingredients

items: 1 cup dried chickpeas (soaked overnight, not cooked)

recipe.text: Instructions
1. Drain soaked chickpeas very well and pat dry. They should be swollen and soft but still completely raw - do not cook them!
2. Add chickpeas, onion, garlic, herbs, and all spices to a food processor. Pulse until the mixture is finely ground but not pureed - it should look like coarse sand with visible green flecks.
3. Transfer to a bowl and refrigerate for at least 1 hour (or up to 24 hours). This helps the mixture firm up and makes shaping easier.
4. After chilling, add baking soda, flour, and sesame seeds. Mix well. The mixture should hold together when squeezed. If too wet, add a bit more flour.
5. Heat 3 inches of oil in a deep pot to 350°F (175°C). Use a thermometer - proper temperature is crucial for crispy falafel.
6. Shape mixture into small patties or balls (about 1.5 inches). A falafel scoop makes this easy, or use two spoons. Don't make them too large or the inside won't cook.
7. Carefully drop falafel into hot oil, frying 6-8 at a time. Fry for 3-4 minutes, turning once, until deep golden brown all over.
8. Drain on paper towels. Serve hot in pita with tahini, Israeli salad, pickles, and hot sauce. Or serve over hummus with salads for a bowl.

title: Thai Green Curry
description: Aromatic green curry with chicken, bamboo shoots, and Thai basil in coconut milk. Rich, creamy, and perfectly balanced heat.

recipe.text: Thai green curry is all about balancing flavors - spicy, sweet, salty, and herbal. Using quality curry paste and fish sauce makes all the difference. Don't skip the Thai basil!
Ingredients

items: 1 lb chicken breast or thighs, thinly sliced
1 tbsp palm sugar or brown sugar

recipe.text: Instructions
1. Heat oil in a wok or large deep pan over medium-high heat. Add curry paste and fry for 1-2 minutes until fragrant and the oil begins to separate from the paste.
2. Add chicken and stir-fry until just cooked through, about 3-4 minutes.
3. Shake the coconut milk can well, then add it to the pan along with the chicken stock. Stir and bring to a simmer.
4. Add fish sauce, sugar, eggplant, bamboo shoots, and kaffir lime leaves. Simmer for 10 minutes until vegetables are tender.
5. Add bell pepper and cook for 2-3 more minutes. Taste and adjust seasoning - add more fish sauce for saltiness, sugar for sweetness, or curry paste for heat.
6. Remove from heat and stir in Thai basil leaves and lime juice. Serve immediately over jasmine rice.

title: Authentic Japanese Ramen
description: Rich pork bone broth with springy noodles, tender chashu pork, soft-boiled eggs, and traditional toppings. A labor of love worth every hour.

recipe.text: Making ramen from scratch is a commitment, but the result is restaurant-quality tonkotsu (pork bone) ramen that will impress anyone. The broth takes time, but most of it is hands-off simmering.
For the Broth (Tonkotsu)
For Chashu Pork
Toppings & Assembly
Instructions

1. Blanch the bones: Bring a large pot of water to boil. Add pork bones and trotters, boil for 10 minutes. Drain and rinse bones thoroughly under cold water to remove scum. This step is crucial for clear, non-bitter broth.

2. Make the broth: Place cleaned bones in a large pot and cover with cold water by 2 inches. Bring to a boil over high heat, then reduce to maintain a rolling boil. Add onion, garlic, ginger, and green onions. Boil for 8-12 hours, adding water as needed to keep bones covered. The longer it cooks, the richer and more milky-white the broth becomes.

3. Make chashu: While broth simmers, roll pork belly tightly and tie with kitchen string. Brown all sides in a pot. Add soy sauce, mirin, sake, sugar, garlic, and ginger with just enough water to cover halfway. Simmer covered for 2 hours, turning occasionally. Let cool in liquid, then slice.

4. Prepare soft-boiled eggs: Bring eggs to room temperature. Boil water, gently lower eggs in, and cook for exactly 6 minutes. Transfer to ice water immediately. Peel and marinate in diluted chashu braising liquid for at least 1 hour.
5. Strain broth and season with salt to taste. Keep hot.
6. Cook ramen noodles according to package instructions (usually 2-3 minutes in boiling water). Drain well.
7. To assemble: Place noodles in a large bowl. Ladle hot broth over noodles. Top with chashu slices, halved soft-boiled egg, nori, menma, green onions, and sesame seeds. Add chili oil if desired.
8. Serve immediately. The noodles will continue to absorb broth, so enjoy while hot!

title: Cacio e Pepe (Roman Cheese and Pepper Pasta)
description: Deceptively simple Roman pasta with just pecorino cheese, black pepper, and pasta water creating a silky, creamy sauce. Technique is everything.

recipe.text: Cacio e Pepe is one of Rome's iconic pastas, and it's maddeningly simple yet easy to mess up. With only 3 ingredients, technique is everything. The key is creating a creamy emulsion without scrambling the cheese.
Ingredients

items: 2 cups finely grated Pecorino Romano cheese (use good quality)
2 tbsp whole black peppercorns, coarsely ground

recipe.text: Instructions
1. Bring a large pot of water to boil and salt it well. Cook pasta until al dente (about 1-2 minutes less than package directions). Reserve 2 cups of starchy pasta water before draining.
2. While pasta cooks, toast the coarsely ground black pepper in a large dry skillet over medium heat for about 1 minute until fragrant. Remove from heat temporarily.
3. Place the grated Pecorino Romano in a large bowl. Add about 1/2 cup of the hot pasta water and whisk vigorously until you have a smooth, creamy paste. This step prevents clumping.
4. Return the skillet with pepper to medium heat and add butter if using. Add about 1/2 cup pasta water and bring to a simmer.
5. Add the drained pasta to the skillet and toss for 1 minute. Remove from heat (this is crucial - too much heat will make the cheese grainy).
6. Add the cheese-water mixture and toss vigorously, adding more pasta water as needed until you achieve a silky, glossy sauce that coats the pasta. The sauce should be creamy, not clumpy or watery.
7. Serve immediately in warmed bowls with extra grated Pecorino and black pepper on top. Cacio e pepe waits for no one!
Pro Tips

• Use the finest grater you have for the cheese - it melts more easily
• Work quickly and off heat when adding cheese
• If sauce breaks (gets grainy), add a splash of cold water and whisk vigorously
• Practice makes perfect - this dish rewards repetition!

title: Mexican Street Tacos (Tacos al Pastor)
description: Marinated pork with pineapple, cilantro, and onions on small corn tortillas. Inspired by Lebanese shawarma brought to Mexico.

recipe.text: Tacos al Pastor are a beautiful fusion of Lebanese and Mexican cuisine. Traditional versions use a vertical spit like shawarma, but this home version captures the essential flavors perfectly.
For the Marinade
For the Tacos

items: 2 lbs boneless pork shoulder, thinly sliced
Salsa verde or your favorite salsa

recipe.text: Instructions
1. Make the marinade: Remove stems and seeds from dried chilies. Toast them briefly in a dry pan until fragrant, about 30 seconds per side. Soak in hot water for 15 minutes until soft.
2. Blend softened chilies with pineapple juice, vinegar, garlic, achiote paste, and all spices until completely smooth. Season with salt and pepper.
3. Toss pork slices with the marinade in a large bowl or zip-top bag. Refrigerate for at least 4 hours, preferably overnight.

4. Heat a large cast iron skillet or griddle over high heat. Working in batches, cook marinated pork until charred and caramelized, about 2-3 minutes per side. The char is essential for authentic flavor!
5. In the same pan, grill pineapple chunks until caramelized and slightly charred. Chop into small pieces.
6. Chop the cooked pork into small pieces for easier eating.
7. Warm corn tortillas directly over a gas flame or in a hot dry skillet until slightly charred and pliable.
8. Assemble tacos: Stack 2 tortillas (authentic street taco style). Add chopped pork, grilled pineapple, diced onion, and cilantro. Squeeze fresh lime over top. Add salsa if desired.
9. Eat immediately while hot. These are best enjoyed standing up, ideally on a street corner in Mexico City!

title: Indian Butter Chicken (Murgh Makhani)
description: Tender chicken in a rich, creamy tomato-based sauce with butter and cream. The ultimate Indian comfort food.

recipe.text: Butter chicken is the dish that makes people fall in love with Indian food. The key is marinating the chicken in yogurt and spices, then creating a velvety sauce that's perfectly balanced between tangy, sweet, and rich.
For the Chicken Marinade

items: 1.5 lbs boneless chicken thighs, cut into chunks

recipe.text: For the Sauce
Instructions
1. Marinate the chicken: Mix all marinade ingredients in a bowl. Add chicken pieces and coat well. Cover and refrigerate for at least 2 hours (overnight is even better).

2. Cook the chicken: Heat a large skillet over high heat. Add marinated chicken (shake off excess marinade) and cook in batches until charred on the outside but not fully cooked through, about 2 minutes per side. Set aside.
3. Make the sauce: In the same pan, melt butter over medium heat. Add onions and cook for 8-10 minutes until soft and golden. Add garlic and ginger, cook for 1 minute.
4. Stir in tomato paste and cook for 2 minutes. Add crushed tomatoes and all spices. Simmer for 10 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the sauce thickens and oil begins to separate.
5. For extra smoothness, blend the sauce with an immersion blender (optional but recommended).
6. Stir in cream and honey. Add the partially cooked chicken and any accumulated juices. Simmer for 10-12 minutes until chicken is fully cooked and sauce is luxurious.
7. Crush fenugreek leaves between your palms and add to the sauce. Stir and let it simmer for 1-2 more minutes. Taste and adjust salt.
8. Garnish with fresh cilantro and a drizzle of cream. Serve with basmati rice or naan bread.

title: Korean Bibimbap
description: Mixed rice bowl with seasoned vegetables, gochujang, fried egg, and optional meat. Colorful, nutritious, and endlessly customizable.

recipe.text: Bibimbap literally means 'mixed rice' - a harmony of flavors, colors, and textures in one bowl. Each component is seasoned individually, then mixed together with spicy gochujang sauce. The crispy rice at the bottom (if using a hot stone bowl) is the best part!
Base & Protein

items: 1/2 lb beef bulgogi or ground beef (optional)

recipe.text: Vegetables (Namul)

items: Sesame oil and salt for seasoning each vegetable

recipe.text: Gochujang Sauce
Instructions

1. Prepare vegetables: Each vegetable should be cooked and seasoned separately. Blanch spinach for 30 seconds, squeeze dry, and season with sesame oil and salt. Do the same with bean sprouts (1 minute blanching).
2. Sauté carrot strips in a little oil until tender, 2-3 minutes. Season with salt and sesame oil. Repeat with zucchini (cook quickly to keep some crunch) and mushrooms.
3. If using beef: Mix thinly sliced beef with soy sauce, sesame oil, and garlic. Sauté over high heat until cooked through, about 3-4 minutes.
4. Make gochujang sauce: Whisk all sauce ingredients together until smooth.
5. Fry eggs sunny-side up so the yolks are still runny.
6. Assemble: Divide rice among 4 bowls. Arrange each vegetable in its own section around the bowl, creating a colorful wheel. Add beef in the center (if using). Top with a fried egg.
7. Serve with gochujang sauce on the side or drizzled over. To eat: Mix everything together vigorously with your spoon, breaking the yolk so it coats the rice. The mixing is essential!
Dolsot Bibimbap Variation
For crispy rice: Heat a stone bowl (dolsot) until very hot. Brush with sesame oil, add rice, then arrange toppings. Let sit for 2-3 minutes to create a crispy rice crust on the bottom.

title: Spanish Seafood Paella
description: Saffron-infused rice with shrimp, mussels, and squid cooked in a wide pan. The pride of Valencia, complete with crispy socarrat.

recipe.text: Paella is not just a dish, it's a ritual. The key is building flavor layers and achieving the socarrat - the crispy, caramelized rice crust at the bottom. Once you add the rice, don't stir! That's the secret.
Ingredients

items: 1 lb large shrimp, peeled and deveined
1/2 lb squid, cleaned and cut into rings
2 cups Spanish bomba or calasparra rice
4 cups seafood or fish stock, heated
Lemon wedges and parsley for serving

recipe.text: Instructions
1. Steep saffron in 1/4 cup of the hot stock for 10 minutes. This releases its color and flavor.

2. Heat olive oil in a large paella pan or wide shallow skillet (14-16 inches) over medium-high heat. Season shrimp and squid with salt. Sear shrimp for 1 minute per side, then remove. Sear squid for 1 minute, remove. These will finish cooking later.
3. In the same pan, sauté onion and bell pepper for 5 minutes. Add garlic and cook 1 minute. Add tomatoes and smoked paprika, cook for 3-4 minutes until thick.
4. Add rice and stir to coat with the sofrito (tomato mixture), about 2 minutes. This toasting adds flavor.
5. Add the hot stock (including the saffron mixture) and bay leaf. Season with salt and pepper. Stir once to distribute rice evenly, then DON'T STIR AGAIN. This is crucial for socarrat.
6. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat to medium-low. Let simmer uncovered for 15 minutes without stirring.
7. Nestle mussels into the rice (hinge side down). Scatter peas over top. Add shrimp and squid back to the pan. Cook for 8-10 more minutes until mussels open and rice is tender.
8. Increase heat to high for the last 1-2 minutes to create the socarrat (crispy bottom). Listen for crackling sounds and smell the toasty aroma.
9. Remove from heat and cover with a kitchen towel. Let rest for 5 minutes. Garnish with lemon wedges and parsley. Serve directly from the pan - that's tradition!

title: Vietnamese Pho
description: Aromatic beef broth with rice noodles, thinly sliced beef, and fresh herbs. Vietnam's beloved comfort soup with complex, delicate flavors.

recipe.text: Pho is all about the broth - clear, aromatic, and deeply beefy with warm spices. Traditional versions simmer for 24 hours, but this streamlined recipe captures the essence in a more manageable time.
For the Broth

items: 3 lbs beef bones (knuckle and leg bones)

recipe.text: For Serving

items: 1/2 lb eye of round steak, thinly sliced

recipe.text: Instructions
1. Parboil bones and brisket: Place in a large pot, cover with water, and bring to a boil. Boil for 5 minutes, then drain and rinse bones thoroughly. This removes impurities for a clear broth.
2. Char aromatics: Place onion halves and ginger (cut side down) directly on a gas flame or under the broiler until blackened and fragrant, about 3-4 minutes. This adds deep, smoky flavor.
3. Toast spices: In a dry pan over medium heat, toast star anise, cloves, cinnamon, coriander, and fennel until fragrant, about 2-3 minutes. Don't burn them!

4. Make the broth: Return cleaned bones and brisket to the pot. Cover with 5 quarts of cold water. Add charred onions and ginger, toasted spices, fish sauce, and sugar. Bring to a boil, then reduce to the gentlest simmer.

5. Simmer for 6-8 hours, skimming impurities from the surface every 30 minutes for the first 2 hours. Don't let it boil vigorously - you want a crystal-clear broth. Add water if needed to keep bones covered.
6. After 3 hours, remove brisket and let cool. Slice thinly against the grain for serving.
7. Strain broth through a fine-mesh sieve. Season with additional fish sauce and salt to taste. The broth should be flavorful but delicate.
8. Prepare noodles: Soak rice noodles in warm water for 20 minutes. When ready to serve, blanch in boiling water for 10-15 seconds until tender. Drain well.

9. Assemble: Place noodles in large bowls. Top with sliced brisket and paper-thin raw beef slices. Ladle boiling hot broth over everything (the broth cooks the raw beef). Serve with a plate of herbs, bean sprouts, lime, jalapeños, and sauces for customization.
10. To eat: Squeeze lime juice, add herbs and sprouts to taste, add sauces if desired. Mix and enjoy while steaming hot!

title: Greek Moussaka
description: Layered casserole with spiced meat sauce, fried eggplant, and creamy béchamel. Greece's answer to lasagna, rich and comforting.

recipe.text: Moussaka is a labor of love with three distinct components that come together into something magical. The key is properly preparing the eggplant and making a rich, cinnamon-spiced meat sauce.
For the Eggplant
For the Meat Sauce
For the Béchamel
Instructions
1. Prepare eggplant: Sprinkle eggplant slices generously with salt and place in a colander. Let sit for 30 minutes to draw out moisture and bitterness. Rinse and pat very dry.
2. Brush eggplant slices lightly with olive oil. Arrange on baking sheets and bake at 400°F (200°C) for 20-25 minutes until golden and tender. This is healthier than frying and less oily.
3. Make meat sauce: Heat olive oil in a large pot. Brown the ground meat, breaking it up, until no longer pink. Add onions and cook for 8 minutes until soft. Add garlic and cook 1 minute.

4. Add wine and let it reduce by half. Stir in crushed tomatoes, tomato paste, cinnamon, allspice, and bay leaf. Season with salt and pepper. Simmer for 30-40 minutes until thick and rich. Remove bay leaf.

5. Make béchamel: Melt butter in a saucepan over medium heat. Whisk in flour and cook for 2 minutes (don't let it brown). Gradually whisk in warm milk, stirring constantly until smooth and thick, about 8-10 minutes.
6. Remove from heat. Whisk in beaten eggs quickly (tempering them), then add Parmesan, nutmeg, salt, and white pepper. The sauce should be thick and creamy.
7. Assemble: In a 9x13 inch baking dish, layer half the eggplant slices. Spread all the meat sauce over them. Layer remaining eggplant on top. Pour béchamel over everything, spreading to the edges.
8. Bake at 350°F (175°C) for 45-50 minutes until the top is golden brown and bubbling. The béchamel should form a beautiful crust.
9. Let rest for 20 minutes before cutting - this is essential for clean slices and allows flavors to settle. Serve with a simple Greek salad.

title: Sichuan Mapo Tofu
description: Silky tofu in spicy, numbing chili oil sauce with ground pork. The famous Sichuan dish with málà (numbing-spicy) flavor.

recipe.text: Mapo tofu is all about the málà sensation - the combination of numbing Sichuan peppercorns and spicy chili oil. It's complex, deeply savory, and incredibly addictive. Don't skip the Sichuan peppercorns!
Ingredients

items: 1 lb soft or silken tofu, cut into 1-inch cubes
2 tsp Sichuan peppercorns, toasted and ground
2 tsp cornstarch mixed with 2 tbsp water

recipe.text: Instructions
1. Prepare tofu: Bring a pot of water to boil with a pinch of salt. Gently add tofu cubes and simmer for 2 minutes. This firms them up and seasons them. Drain gently and set aside.
2. Toast Sichuan peppercorns in a dry pan over medium heat until fragrant, about 2 minutes. Grind in a mortar and pestle or spice grinder. Set aside.
3. Heat wok or large pan over high heat. Add oil and ground pork. Cook, breaking it up, until crispy and browned, about 4-5 minutes. Don't stir too much - you want some crispy bits.
4. Push pork to the side. Add chili bean paste and fermented black beans to the center. Fry in the oil for about 1 minute until fragrant and the oil turns red.
5. Add garlic and ginger, stir-fry for 30 seconds. Add chili oil (including the chili sediment for extra spice and flavor).
6. Pour in stock, soy sauce, and sugar. Bring to a boil. Gently slide in the tofu cubes. Reduce heat and simmer for 5 minutes so tofu absorbs the sauce. Don't stir aggressively or tofu will break.
7. Add cornstarch slurry and stir gently until sauce thickens. Add half the ground Sichuan peppercorns and half the green onions. Stir gently.
8. Transfer to serving dish. Top with remaining ground Sichuan peppercorns and green onions. The numbing sensation should hit right after the spice. Serve over steamed rice.
Pro Tip
For vegetarian version, replace pork with shiitake mushrooms (minced) and use vegetable stock. The dish is just as flavorful!

title: French Coq au Vin
description: Chicken braised in red wine with mushrooms, pearl onions, and bacon. A rustic French classic that tastes like you're dining in Burgundy.

recipe.text: Coq au vin is French comfort food at its finest. The chicken becomes incredibly tender as it braises in wine, and the sauce is rich, velvety, and deeply satisfying. Perfect for a cold evening.
Ingredients

items: 1 whole chicken (3-4 lbs), cut into 8 pieces
6 oz thick-cut bacon, cut into lardons
1 bottle (750ml) dry red wine (Burgundy or Pinot Noir)

recipe.text: Instructions
1. Pat chicken pieces completely dry and season generously with salt and pepper. This is crucial for good browning.
2. In a large Dutch oven, cook bacon over medium heat until crispy, about 5-6 minutes. Remove with a slotted spoon and set aside, leaving the fat in the pot.
3. Working in batches, brown chicken pieces in the bacon fat, skin-side down first, until deep golden brown on both sides, about 4-5 minutes per side. Don't crowd the pan. Remove and set aside.

4. In the same pot, add pearl onions and cook until golden, about 5 minutes. Add mushrooms and cook until browned, 5 more minutes. Add carrots and garlic, cook 2 minutes. Stir in tomato paste and cook 1 minute.

5. Add cognac and carefully ignite with a long match to flambé (or just let it simmer to cook off the alcohol). Once flames die down, add red wine and stock. Scrape up all the browned bits from the bottom - this is flavor gold!
6. Return chicken and bacon to the pot. Add thyme and bay leaves. Bring to a simmer, then cover and transfer to a 325°F (165°C) oven. Braise for 1.5 hours until chicken is fall-off-the-bone tender.
7. Remove chicken and vegetables to a serving platter and keep warm. Strain the braising liquid into a saucepan.

8. Make beurre manié: Mash 2 tbsp butter with 2 tbsp flour until smooth. Bring braising liquid to a simmer and whisk in the beurre manié bit by bit until sauce thickens to coat the back of a spoon. This should take about 5 minutes.
9. Taste and adjust seasoning. Pour sauce over chicken and vegetables. Garnish with fresh parsley. Serve with crusty bread, mashed potatoes, or buttered egg noodles to soak up the incredible sauce.

title: Brazilian Feijoada
description: Brazil's national dish - hearty black bean stew with various pork cuts, sausages, and beef. Traditionally served with rice, orange slices, and farofa.

recipe.text: Feijoada is the soul of Brazilian cuisine - a rich, smoky black bean stew cooked low and slow with various meats. It's traditionally made on Wednesdays and Saturdays, served as a communal feast with all the fixings.
Ingredients

items: 1 lb dried black beans, soaked overnight
1 lb pork shoulder, cut into chunks
1/2 lb smoked sausage (linguiça or kielbasa), sliced

recipe.text: Traditional Accompaniments
Instructions
1. Drain soaked beans and place in a large pot. Add pork ribs and cover with water by 2 inches. Bring to a boil, then reduce to a simmer. Cook for 1 hour, skimming foam occasionally.
2. Meanwhile, in a large skillet, render the bacon until crispy. Remove bacon and set aside. In the bacon fat, brown pork shoulder chunks on all sides, about 8 minutes total. Set aside.
3. In the same skillet, brown the sausage slices. Set aside with other meats.
4. After beans have cooked for 1 hour, add the browned pork shoulder, bacon, sausage, and bay leaf to the pot. Add more water if needed to cover everything. Simmer for another hour.

5. Make the refogado (flavor base): Heat olive oil in a pan. Sauté onions until golden, about 8 minutes. Add garlic and cook 1 minute. Add tomatoes and cook until they break down, about 5 minutes. Season with salt, pepper, and paprika.

6. Remove 2 ladles of beans from the pot and mash them. This will help thicken the stew. Return mashed beans to the pot along with the refogado. Squeeze in the orange quarters and drop them into the stew.
7. Simmer for 30 more minutes, stirring occasionally, until beans are creamy and meats are fall-apart tender. The consistency should be thick but still soupy.
8. Remove orange quarters and bay leaf. Taste and adjust salt. Feijoada should be well-seasoned and deeply savory.
9. Serve in large bowls over white rice. Arrange all the traditional accompaniments on the table: collard greens, fresh orange slices, farofa, and vinagrete. Mix everything together as you eat!
Make-Ahead Note
Feijoada actually tastes better the next day as flavors meld. It's perfect for meal prep or feeding a crowd!
